captions.text:
Earth's ecosystems have always been changing,
with species mixing and mingling thanks to

migrations, freak events, and slow creeping
expansions. But since we humans arrived on

the scene, we've put things into fast-forward,
moving plants, animals, and other organisms

around the globe -- whether intentionally
or not.

Once in a while, one of these transplants
might have an evolutionary quirk -- like deadly

poison, a lack of predators, or a voracious
appetite -- that unexpectedly helps it dominate

its new territory. Earthworms, for example,
were introduced into North America by European settlers

and have been inching across the continent
ever since - tilling soil and improving crop
yields as they go.

But if a newcomer starts to harm us or a part
of the environment we care about, we'll call

it an "invasive species." Technically-speaking,
humans aren't "invasive," because we don't

usually consider ourselves an ecological threat
to... ourselves.

But other species certainly are. One way they
get our attention is by costing us money.

A lot of money. The US spends billions of
dollars fighting invasive weeds like the pretty

but pesky yellow rocket flower that chokes
fields and creeps onto golf courses and lawns.

Other invaders wreak so much havoc on fragile
ecosystems that we can't help but notice even

if billions aren't at stake. For example,
the yellow crazy ant - a likely native of

Southeast Asia - has been eating many beloved
and endangered Australian creatures since

its arrival several decades ago. These little
ants feast on nearly anything and everything

in their path - insects, amphibians, birds,
small mammals, even the famous red crabs on

Australia's Christmas Island, which used to
keep the island's undergrowth in check; without
them, the ecosystem has veered into chaos.

But noticing invasive species is easy - dealing
with them is the real challenge.

When we brought rabbits to New Zealand for
food and fur, they escaped and bred like...well...rabbits,

overrunning the country. So we introduced
ferrets to control the rabbits; but they too

spread like wildfire, generally ignoring the
rabbits while gobbling up rare species like

the now nearly-extinct kakapo. New Zealand
is still overrun by both furry fiends, and

this is just one of many well-meaning attempts
at biological control that have ended in disaster.

The best way to fight an invasion is to first
arm ourselves with knowledge: Instead of trying

to kill Australia's yellow crazy ants by just
spraying insecticide everywhere, we've learned

that the best approach is a year-long multi-step
assault that specifically targets ant-riddled

areas at the times when the egg-laying queens
are mature and susceptible to our treatments.

Then we spread two kinds of bait for the workers
to bring back to the nest - one kills, and

the other sterilizes the queens. Neither poison
is perfect, but executed together, they can
knock out a whopping 99 percent of the population.

But with many invasives, even 99% isn't enough,
because it doesn't remove whatever advantage

gave the invaders an edge in the first place.
So unless we honest-to-goodness get rid of

every reproductively active individual, eventually
they'll return as vigorously as before, keeping
us constantly on our toes.

We really just need to stop moving potential
troublemakers around in the first place, leaving

bunnies where they belong and making sure
ants and earthworms don't stow away in ships,

cars, or excavators. But in a modern, globalized
world, this is easier said than done. For

those species that we do accidentally (or
intentionally) let loose only to see them

spread wildly out of control, our best hope
is to learn as much as we can about their

habits and their biology - only then do we
have a chance of keeping their harmful "ant"-ics
at bay.

title: Invasion of the Yellow Crazy Ants!

+ThatGastrodon exactly. 
we are extremely destructive, i will give them that. but the only 
difference between us and the animals is the scale.

Ants, for example, have full scale war with each other. they kill millions 
of eachother and completely wipe out their rival colony.
termites completely destory the environment around them and exploit 
resources on a relatively massive scale to build their colony.
large cats like tigers kill for sport. their instincts drive them to take 
down another animal, play with it, then leave the carcass.
whales never stop eating. there is no such thing as a full whale.they just 
swim around with their mouths open and eat all the time...

war and genocide,
destruction of the environment for resources,
killing for fun,
gluttony and overconsumption,

these are behaviors are usually used as arguments against humans but you 
don't have to look very far to find it in nature. 
as i said it is just the scale we do it on that sets us apart. if ants had 
tiny nukes, there would be millions of little craters everywhere
comments.author: Ty Guy

comments.text:
It just kills me how people seem to think that nature is somehow peaceful, 
when in reality it's anything but. To be honest, humans are the most 
peaceful species on the planet, and our tendency to use our minds over our 
fists is exactly why we've become the dominant species on the planet, and 
why we currently live the most luxurious lives of any species in the 
history of Earth. Humanity is an incredible, wonderful thing, and people 
seem to look for any reason to denigrate it.
comments.author: ThatGastrodon

comments.text:

comments.author: Ty Guy

comments.text:
It's funny how our culture has gone from celebrating humanity through 
humanitarianism (which, I might add, is pretty much how every other species 
on the planet thinks) to the self-flagellating environmentalism of today. 

Ever since realizing that the Earth is constantly changing its diversity, 
and more importantly, letting the evolutionary winners split into new 
species, I've come to peace with the fact that this obsession is just 
humanity trying to work against nature. There's no such thing as an 
"invasive species", because that's exactly how nature works in the first 
place. Humans should look out for our species primarily, and let nature do 
what it's always done: adapt.
comments.author: ThatGastrodon

comments.author: Jack Hoff

comments.text:
The problem is that we view humans as separated from animals. 
We consider ourselves as outside the ecosystems we live in (and thus our 
actions as well), but we are no more or less a part of it as the wolves, 
ants, or bacteria that lives on our skin.

We view extinction as a bad thing. A negative result of something.
We view it this way because we are self aware as a species, and therefore 
view our own extinction as a negative.
It's not.
All animals die eventually, most within just a few years, some within a day.
It makes no difference to the individual if the species continues past that 
point.
Average humans, as intelligent as we are, at most only think 2-3 
generations into the future even for our own species. Sometimes less.
Ants are incapable of thinking this way at all, instead they are wired to 
prioritize the colony for a reason they are completely unaware of.

Extinction is natural.
I am not saying we should make it a goal to expedite the process on 
purpose, since that can negatively impact our own survival, but worrying 
about one species taking over another naturally... is retarded.
comments.author: Ty Guy

comments.text:
I agree. I am sick of all these specist and bigoted people. Science has

anyway, therefor trying to preserve current ecosystems for posterity for 
our children to experience what their ancestors experienced is just stupid 
and pointless. Diversity is good, especially when it results in more 
species going extinct than remain extant.

homogeneity through extinctions and "invasive" species events. It's sad.

optimistically about these ridiculous trends. Maybe all the carbon we're 
emitting will feed a future garden of global proportions, and we'll all 
live harmoniously with the plants, and the animals, and the robots, 
together exploring space/time forever. That would be pretty sweet, yeah? 
Come on! Let's get it together people.﻿

on Galapogus Island they can hire me.  All i need is food and supplies for 
the weapon i choose (their cost to get for me), and a place to live, all 
paid for by them and I will stay there 1 yr and fix the issues. :)﻿
comments.author: Brian M

comments.text:
Oh my gosh! The bites of those little yellow (I call them 'red') ants burn 
and hurts really bad. The black-colored ants are better. ﻿
comments.author: Aubzy102

comments.text:
ants again...tell me about it. In in southern united states we have a 
similar problem with fire ants, which were originally imported from the 
eastern world. They live in huge colonies, and their bites sting like fire, 
hence the name.﻿
comments.author: Joe Reynolds

comments.text: reminds meh of an episode from tarzan :P ﻿
